trans-unit.target: Learn how to diagnose and fix scalability issues in your mobile services backed by SQL Database

trans-unit.source: Azure Mobile Services makes it very easy to get started and build an app that connects to a cloud-hosted backend that stores data in a SQL database.
trans-unit.target: Azure Mobile Services makes it very easy to get started and build an app that connects to a cloud-hosted backend that stores data in a SQL database.

trans-unit.source: As your app grows, scaling your service instances is as simple as adjusting scale settings in the portal to add more computational and networking capacity.
trans-unit.target: As your app grows, scaling your service instances is as simple as adjusting scale settings in the portal to add more computational and networking capacity.

trans-unit.source: However, scaling the SQL database backing your service requires some proactive planning and monitoring as the service receives more load.
trans-unit.target: However, scaling the SQL database backing your service requires some proactive planning and monitoring as the service receives more load.

trans-unit.source: This document will walk you through a set of best practices to ensure continued great performance of your SQL-backed mobile services.
trans-unit.target: This document will walk you through a set of best practices to ensure continued great performance of your SQL-backed mobile services.

trans-unit.source: If you suspect your mobile service is experiencing problems under load, the first place to check is the Dashboard tab for your service in the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: If you suspect your mobile service is experiencing problems under load, the first place to check is the Dashboard tab for your service in the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Some of the things to verify here:
trans-unit.target: Some of the things to verify here:

trans-unit.source: Your usage meters including API Calls and Active Devices meters are not over quota
trans-unit.target: Your usage meters including API Calls and Active Devices meters are not over quota

trans-unit.source: Endpoint Monitoring status indicates service is up (only available if service is using the Standard tier and Endpoint Monitoring is enabled)
trans-unit.target: Endpoint Monitoring status indicates service is up (only available if service is using the Standard tier and Endpoint Monitoring is enabled)

trans-unit.source: If any of the above is not true, consider adjusting your scale settings on the Scale tab.
trans-unit.target: If any of the above is not true, consider adjusting your scale settings on the Scale tab.

trans-unit.source: If that does not address the issue, you can proceed and investigate whether Azure SQL Database may be the source of the issue.

trans-unit.source: It is important to understand the different database tiers you have at your disposal to ensure you've picked the right tier given your app's needs.
trans-unit.target: It is important to understand the different database tiers you have at your disposal to ensure you've picked the right tier given your app's needs.

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Database offers two different database editions and three different service tiers:
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database offers two different database editions and three different service tiers:

trans-unit.source: Web and Business Editions (retired)
trans-unit.target: Web and Business Editions (retired)

trans-unit.source: Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers
trans-unit.target: Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers

trans-unit.source: While the Web and Business Editions are fully supported, they will be retired on September 12, 2015 as discussed in <linkText>Web and Business Edition Sunset FAQ</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: While the Web and Business Editions are fully supported, they will be retired on September 12, 2015 as discussed in <linkText>Web and Business Edition Sunset FAQ</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: We encourage new customers to start using the Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers in preparation for this change.
trans-unit.target: We encourage new customers to start using the Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers in preparation for this change.

trans-unit.source: They provide a variety of monitoring capabilities that make it even easier to understand and troubleshoot database performance.
trans-unit.target: They provide a variety of monitoring capabilities that make it even easier to understand and troubleshoot database performance.

trans-unit.source: All new mobile services are created using one of the new service tiers.
trans-unit.target: All new mobile services are created using one of the new service tiers.

trans-unit.source: To convert a mobile service using the Web and Business Edition to the Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers, follow these steps.
trans-unit.target: To convert a mobile service using the Web and Business Edition to the Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers, follow these steps.

trans-unit.source: Launch the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Launch the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Select +NEW in the toolbar and then pick Data Services, SQL Database, Quick Create.
trans-unit.target: Select +NEW in the toolbar and then pick Data Services, SQL Database, Quick Create.

trans-unit.source: Enter a database name and then select New SQL database server in the Server field.
trans-unit.target: Enter a database name and then select New SQL database server in the Server field.

trans-unit.source: This will create a server that is using the new Basic, Standard, or Premium service tier.
trans-unit.target: This will create a server that is using the new Basic, Standard, or Premium service tier.

trans-unit.source: Fill out the rest of the fields and select Create SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Fill out the rest of the fields and select Create SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: This will create a 100MB database using the Basic tier.
trans-unit.target: This will create a 100MB database using the Basic tier.

trans-unit.source: Configure your mobile service to use the database you just created.
trans-unit.target: Configure your mobile service to use the database you just created.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the Configure tab for that service and select Change Database in the toolbar.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the Configure tab for that service and select Change Database in the toolbar.

trans-unit.source: On the next screen, select Use an existing SQL database in the SQL Database field and then select Next.
trans-unit.target: On the next screen, select Use an existing SQL database in the SQL Database field and then select Next.

trans-unit.source: On the next screen be sure to pick the database you created in step 5, then select OK.
trans-unit.target: On the next screen be sure to pick the database you created in step 5, then select OK.

trans-unit.source: Here are some recommendations on selecting the right tier for your database:
trans-unit.target: Here are some recommendations on selecting the right tier for your database:

trans-unit.source: Basic - use at development time or for small production services where you only expect to make a single database query at a time
trans-unit.target: Basic - use at development time or for small production services where you only expect to make a single database query at a time

trans-unit.source: Standard - use for production services where you expect multiple concurrent database queries
trans-unit.target: Standard - use for production services where you expect multiple concurrent database queries

trans-unit.source: Premium - use for large scale production services with many concurrent queries, high peak load, and expected low latency for every request.
trans-unit.target: Premium - use for large scale production services with many concurrent queries, high peak load, and expected low latency for every request.

trans-unit.source: For more information on when to use each tier, see <linkText>Reasons to Use the New Service Tiers</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For more information on when to use each tier, see <linkText>Reasons to Use the New Service Tiers</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: If the metrics indicate your database is incurring high utilization, consider scaling up the database to a higher service tier as a first mitigation step.
trans-unit.target: If the metrics indicate your database is incurring high utilization, consider scaling up the database to a higher service tier as a first mitigation step.

trans-unit.source: To immediately resolve issues, consider using the Scale tab for your database to scale up your database.
trans-unit.target: To immediately resolve issues, consider using the Scale tab for your database to scale up your database.

trans-unit.source: This will result in an increase in your bill.

trans-unit.source: As soon as possible, consider these additional mitigation steps:
trans-unit.target: As soon as possible, consider these additional mitigation steps:

trans-unit.source: Tune your database. It is frequently possible to reduce database utilization and avoid having to scale to a higher tier by optimizing your database.
trans-unit.target: Tune your database. It is frequently possible to reduce database utilization and avoid having to scale to a higher tier by optimizing your database.

trans-unit.source: Consider your service architecture. Frequently your service load is not distributed evenly over time but contains "spikes" of high demand.
trans-unit.target: Consider your service architecture. Frequently your service load is not distributed evenly over time but contains "spikes" of high demand.

trans-unit.source: Instead of scaling the database up to handle the spikes, and having it go underutilized during periods of low demand, it is frequently possible to adjust the service architecture to avoid such spikes, or to handle them without incurring database hits.
trans-unit.target: Instead of scaling the database up to handle the spikes, and having it go underutilized during periods of low demand, it is frequently possible to adjust the service architecture to avoid such spikes, or to handle them without incurring database hits.

trans-unit.source: The remaining sections of this document contain tailored guidance to help with implementing these mitigations.
trans-unit.target: The remaining sections of this document contain tailored guidance to help with implementing these mitigations.

trans-unit.source: When you start to see problems with your query performance, the first thing you should investigate is the design of your indexes.
trans-unit.target: When you start to see problems with your query performance, the first thing you should investigate is the design of your indexes.

trans-unit.source: Indexes are important because they directly affect how the SQL engine executes a query.
trans-unit.target: Indexes are important because they directly affect how the SQL engine executes a query.

trans-unit.source: For instance, if you often need to look up an element by a certain field, you should consider adding an index for that column.
trans-unit.target: For instance, if you often need to look up an element by a certain field, you should consider adding an index for that column.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the SQL engine will be forced to perform a table scan and read each physical record (or at least the query column) and the records could be substantially spread out on disk.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the SQL engine will be forced to perform a table scan and read each physical record (or at least the query column) and the records could be substantially spread out on disk.

trans-unit.source: So, if you are frequently doing WHERE or JOIN statements on particular columns, you should make sure you index them.
trans-unit.target: So, if you are frequently doing WHERE or JOIN statements on particular columns, you should make sure you index them.

trans-unit.source: See the section <linkText>Creating Indexes</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See the section <linkText>Creating Indexes</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: If indexes are so great and table scans are so bad, does that mean you should index every column in your table, just to be safe?
trans-unit.target: If indexes are so great and table scans are so bad, does that mean you should index every column in your table, just to be safe?

trans-unit.source: The short answer is, "probably not."
trans-unit.target: The short answer is, "probably not."

trans-unit.source: Indexes take up space and have overhead themselves: every time there is an insert in a table, the index structures for each of the indexed columns need to be updated.
trans-unit.target: Indexes take up space and have overhead themselves: every time there is an insert in a table, the index structures for each of the indexed columns need to be updated.

trans-unit.source: See below for guidelines on how to choose your column indexes.
trans-unit.target: See below for guidelines on how to choose your column indexes.

trans-unit.source: As mentioned above, it's not always better to add more indexes to a table, because indexes themselves can be costly, both in terms of performance and storage overhead.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned above, it's not always better to add more indexes to a table, because indexes themselves can be costly, both in terms of performance and storage overhead.

trans-unit.source: Consider adding indexes to columns that are frequently used in predicates (e.g., WHERE clauses) and join conditions, while balancing the database considerations below.
trans-unit.target: Consider adding indexes to columns that are frequently used in predicates (e.g., WHERE clauses) and join conditions, while balancing the database considerations below.

trans-unit.source: Write queries that insert or modify as many rows as possible in a single statement, instead of using multiple queries to update the same rows.
trans-unit.target: Write queries that insert or modify as many rows as possible in a single statement, instead of using multiple queries to update the same rows.

trans-unit.source: When there is only one statement, the database engine can better optimize how it maintains indexes.
trans-unit.target: When there is only one statement, the database engine can better optimize how it maintains indexes.

trans-unit.source: Large numbers of indexes on a table affect the performance of INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, and MERGE statements because all indexes must be adjusted appropriately as data in the table changes.
trans-unit.target: Large numbers of indexes on a table affect the performance of INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, and MERGE statements because all indexes must be adjusted appropriately as data in the table changes.

trans-unit.source: For heavily updated tables, avoid indexing heavily updated columns.
trans-unit.target: For heavily updated tables, avoid indexing heavily updated columns.

trans-unit.source: For tables that are not frequently updated but that have large volumes of data, use many indexes.
trans-unit.target: For tables that are not frequently updated but that have large volumes of data, use many indexes.

trans-unit.source: This can improve the performance of queries that do not modify data (such as SELECT statements) because the query optimizer will have more options for finding the best access method.
trans-unit.target: This can improve the performance of queries that do not modify data (such as SELECT statements) because the query optimizer will have more options for finding the best access method.

trans-unit.source: Indexing small tables may not be optimal because it can take the query optimizer longer to traverse the index searching for data than to perform a simple table scan.
trans-unit.target: Indexing small tables may not be optimal because it can take the query optimizer longer to traverse the index searching for data than to perform a simple table scan.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, indexes on small tables might never be used, but must still be maintained as data in the table changes.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, indexes on small tables might never be used, but must still be maintained as data in the table changes.

trans-unit.source: Here are a few issues to be aware of when picking the data types for your objects, which in turn translates to the schema of your SQL database.
trans-unit.target: Here are a few issues to be aware of when picking the data types for your objects, which in turn translates to the schema of your SQL database.

trans-unit.source: Tuning the schema can frequently bring significant performance improvements since SQL has custom optimized ways of handling indexing and storage for different data types:
trans-unit.target: Tuning the schema can frequently bring significant performance improvements since SQL has custom optimized ways of handling indexing and storage for different data types:

trans-unit.source: Use the provided ID column.
trans-unit.target: Use the provided ID column.

trans-unit.source: Every mobile service table comes with a default ID column configured as the primary key and has an index set on it.
trans-unit.target: Every mobile service table comes with a default ID column configured as the primary key and has an index set on it.

trans-unit.source: There is no need to create an additional ID column.
trans-unit.target: There is no need to create an additional ID column.

trans-unit.source: Use the correct datatypes in your model. If you know a certain property of your model will be a numeric or boolean, be sure to define it that way in your model instead of as a string.
trans-unit.target: Use the correct datatypes in your model. If you know a certain property of your model will be a numeric or boolean, be sure to define it that way in your model instead of as a string.

trans-unit.source: In the JavaScript backend, use literals such as true instead of "true" and 5 instead of "5".
trans-unit.target: In the JavaScript backend, use literals such as true instead of "true" and 5 instead of "5".

trans-unit.source: In the .NET backend, use the int and bool types when you declare the properties of your model.
trans-unit.target: In the .NET backend, use the int and bool types when you declare the properties of your model.

trans-unit.source: This enables SQL to create the correct schema for those types, which makes queries more efficient.
trans-unit.target: This enables SQL to create the correct schema for those types, which makes queries more efficient.

trans-unit.source: Here are some guidelines to consider when querying the database:
trans-unit.target: Here are some guidelines to consider when querying the database:

trans-unit.source: Always execute join operations in the database. Frequently you will need to combine records from two or more tables where the records being combined share a common field (also known as a join).
trans-unit.target: Always execute join operations in the database. Frequently you will need to combine records from two or more tables where the records being combined share a common field (also known as a join).

trans-unit.source: This operation can be inefficient if performed incorrectly since it may involve pulling down all the entities from both tables and then iterating through all of them.
trans-unit.target: This operation can be inefficient if performed incorrectly since it may involve pulling down all the entities from both tables and then iterating through all of them.

trans-unit.source: This kind of operation is best left to the database itself, but it is sometimes easy to mistakenly perform it on the client or in the mobile service code.
trans-unit.target: This kind of operation is best left to the database itself, but it is sometimes easy to mistakenly perform it on the client or in the mobile service code.

trans-unit.source: Don't perform joins in your app code
trans-unit.target: Don't perform joins in your app code

trans-unit.source: Don't perform joins in your mobile service code.
trans-unit.target: Don't perform joins in your mobile service code.

trans-unit.source: When using the JavaScript backend, be aware that the <linkText>table object</linkText><title></title> does not handle joins.
trans-unit.target: When using the JavaScript backend, be aware that the <linkText>table object</linkText><title></title> does not handle joins.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to use the <linkText>mssql object</linkText><title></title> directly to ensure the join happens in the database.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to use the <linkText>mssql object</linkText><title></title> directly to ensure the join happens in the database.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Join relational tables</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Join relational tables</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If using the .NET backend and querying via LINQ, joins are automatically handled at the database level by Entity Framework.
trans-unit.target: If using the .NET backend and querying via LINQ, joins are automatically handled at the database level by Entity Framework.

trans-unit.source: Implement paging. Querying the database can sometimes result in a large number of records being returned to the client.
trans-unit.target: Implement paging. Querying the database can sometimes result in a large number of records being returned to the client.

trans-unit.source: To minimize the size and latency of operations, consider implementing paging.
trans-unit.target: To minimize the size and latency of operations, consider implementing paging.

trans-unit.source: By default your mobile service will limit any incoming queries to a page size of 50, and you can manually request up to 1,000 records.
trans-unit.target: By default your mobile service will limit any incoming queries to a page size of 50, and you can manually request up to 1,000 records.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see "Return data in pages" for <linkText>Windows Store</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>iOS</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>Android</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>HTML/JavaScript</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>Xamarin</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see "Return data in pages" for <linkText>Windows Store</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>iOS</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>Android</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>HTML/JavaScript</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>Xamarin</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: There is no default page size for queries made from your mobile service code.
trans-unit.target: There is no default page size for queries made from your mobile service code.

trans-unit.source: If your app does not implement paging, or as a defensive measure, consider applying default limits to your queries.
trans-unit.target: If your app does not implement paging, or as a defensive measure, consider applying default limits to your queries.

trans-unit.source: In the JavaScript backend, use the take operator on the query object.
trans-unit.target: In the JavaScript backend, use the take operator on the query object.

trans-unit.source: If using the .NET backend, consider using the [Take method](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/vstudio/bb503062(v=vs.110).aspx) as part of your LINQ query.
trans-unit.target: If using the .NET backend, consider using the [Take method](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/vstudio/bb503062(v=vs.110).aspx) as part of your LINQ query.

trans-unit.source: For more information on improving query design, including how to analyze query plans, see <linkText>Advanced Query Design</linkText><title></title> at the bottom of this document.
trans-unit.target: For more information on improving query design, including how to analyze query plans, see <linkText>Advanced Query Design</linkText><title></title> at the bottom of this document.

trans-unit.source: Imagine a scenario where you are about to send a push notification to all your customers to check out some new content in your app.
trans-unit.target: Imagine a scenario where you are about to send a push notification to all your customers to check out some new content in your app.

trans-unit.source: As they tap on the notification, the app launches, which possibly triggers a call to your mobile service and a query execution against your SQL database.
trans-unit.target: As they tap on the notification, the app launches, which possibly triggers a call to your mobile service and a query execution against your SQL database.

trans-unit.source: As potentially millions of customers take this action over the span of just a few minutes, this will generate a surge of SQL load, which may be orders of magnitude higher than your app's steady state load.
trans-unit.target: As potentially millions of customers take this action over the span of just a few minutes, this will generate a surge of SQL load, which may be orders of magnitude higher than your app's steady state load.

trans-unit.source: This could be addressed by scaling your app to a higher SQL tier during the spike and then scaling it back down, however that solution requires manual intervention and comes with increased cost.
trans-unit.target: This could be addressed by scaling your app to a higher SQL tier during the spike and then scaling it back down, however that solution requires manual intervention and comes with increased cost.

trans-unit.source: Frequently slight tweaks in your mobile service architecture can significantly balance out the load clients drive to your SQL database and eliminate problematic spikes in demand.
trans-unit.target: Frequently slight tweaks in your mobile service architecture can significantly balance out the load clients drive to your SQL database and eliminate problematic spikes in demand.

trans-unit.source: These modifications can often be implemented easily with minimal impact to your customer's experience.
trans-unit.target: These modifications can often be implemented easily with minimal impact to your customer's experience.

trans-unit.source: Here are some examples:
trans-unit.target: Here are some examples:

trans-unit.source: Spread out the load over time. If you control the timing of certain events (for example, a broadcast push notification), which are expected to generate a spike in demand, and the timing of those events is not critical, consider spreading them out over time.
trans-unit.target: Spread out the load over time. If you control the timing of certain events (for example, a broadcast push notification), which are expected to generate a spike in demand, and the timing of those events is not critical, consider spreading them out over time.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, perhaps it is acceptable for your app customers to get notified of the new app content in batches over the span of a day instead of nearly simultaneously.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, perhaps it is acceptable for your app customers to get notified of the new app content in batches over the span of a day instead of nearly simultaneously.

trans-unit.source: Consider batching up your customers into groups which will allow staggered delivery to each batch.
trans-unit.target: Consider batching up your customers into groups which will allow staggered delivery to each batch.

trans-unit.source: If using Notification Hubs, applying an additional tag to track the batch, and then delivering a push notification to that tag provides an easy way to implement this strategy.
trans-unit.target: If using Notification Hubs, applying an additional tag to track the batch, and then delivering a push notification to that tag provides an easy way to implement this strategy.

trans-unit.source: For more information on tags, see <linkText>Use Notification Hubs to send breaking news</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on tags, see <linkText>Use Notification Hubs to send breaking news</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Use Blob and Table Storage whenever appropriate. Frequently the content that the customers will view during the spike is fairly static and doesn't need to be stored in a SQL database since you are unlikely to need relational querying capabilities over that content.
trans-unit.target: Use Blob and Table Storage whenever appropriate. Frequently the content that the customers will view during the spike is fairly static and doesn't need to be stored in a SQL database since you are unlikely to need relational querying capabilities over that content.

trans-unit.source: In that case, consider storing the content in Blob or Table Storage.
trans-unit.target: In that case, consider storing the content in Blob or Table Storage.

trans-unit.source: You can access public blobs in Blob Storage directly from the device.
trans-unit.target: You can access public blobs in Blob Storage directly from the device.

trans-unit.source: To access blobs in a secure way or use Table Storage, you will need to go through a Mobile Services Custom API in order to protect your storage access key.
trans-unit.target: To access blobs in a secure way or use Table Storage, you will need to go through a Mobile Services Custom API in order to protect your storage access key.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Upload images to Azure Storage by using Mobile Services</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Upload images to Azure Storage by using Mobile Services</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Use an in-memory cache.
trans-unit.target: Use an in-memory cache.

trans-unit.source: Another alternative is to store data, which would commonly be accessed during a traffic spike, in an in-memory cache such as <linkText>Azure Cache</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Another alternative is to store data, which would commonly be accessed during a traffic spike, in an in-memory cache such as <linkText>Azure Cache</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This means incoming requests would be able to fetch the information they need from memory, instead of repeatedly querying the database.
trans-unit.target: This means incoming requests would be able to fetch the information they need from memory, instead of repeatedly querying the database.

trans-unit.source: A table or view can contain the following types of indexes:
trans-unit.target: A table or view can contain the following types of indexes:

trans-unit.source: Clustered.
trans-unit.target: Clustered.

trans-unit.source: A clustered index specifies how records are physically stored on disk.
trans-unit.target: A clustered index specifies how records are physically stored on disk.

trans-unit.source: There must be only one clustered index per table, because the data rows themselves can be sorted in only one order.
trans-unit.target: There must be only one clustered index per table, because the data rows themselves can be sorted in only one order.

trans-unit.source: Nonclustered.
trans-unit.target: Nonclustered.

trans-unit.source: Nonclustered indexes are stored separately from data rows and are used to do a lookup based on the index value.
trans-unit.target: Nonclustered indexes are stored separately from data rows and are used to do a lookup based on the index value.

trans-unit.source: All nonclustered indexes on a table use the key values from the clustered index as lookup key.
trans-unit.target: All nonclustered indexes on a table use the key values from the clustered index as lookup key.

trans-unit.source: To provide a real-world analogy: consider a book or a technical manual.
trans-unit.target: To provide a real-world analogy: consider a book or a technical manual.

trans-unit.source: The contents of each page are a record, the page number is the clustered index, and the topic index in the back of the book is a nonclustered index.
trans-unit.target: The contents of each page are a record, the page number is the clustered index, and the topic index in the back of the book is a nonclustered index.

trans-unit.source: Each entry in the topic index points to the clustered index, the page number.
trans-unit.target: Each entry in the topic index points to the clustered index, the page number.

trans-unit.source: By default, the JavaScript backend of Azure Mobile Services sets \_createdAt as the clustered index.
trans-unit.target: By default, the JavaScript backend of Azure Mobile Services sets \_createdAt as the clustered index.

trans-unit.source: If you remove this column, or if you want a different clustered index, be sure to follow the <linkText>clustered index design guidelines</linkText><title></title> below.
trans-unit.target: If you remove this column, or if you want a different clustered index, be sure to follow the <linkText>clustered index design guidelines</linkText><title></title> below.

trans-unit.source: In the .NET backend, the class EntityData defines CreatedAt as a clustered index using the annotation [Index(IsClustered = true)].
trans-unit.target: In the .NET backend, the class EntityData defines CreatedAt as a clustered index using the annotation [Index(IsClustered = true)].

trans-unit.source: Every table should have a clustered index on the column (or columns, in the case of a composite key) with the following properties:
trans-unit.target: Every table should have a clustered index on the column (or columns, in the case of a composite key) with the following properties:

trans-unit.source: Narrow - uses a small datatype, or is a <linkText>composite key[primary and foreign key constraints]</linkText><title></title> of a small number of narrow columns
trans-unit.target: Narrow - uses a small datatype, or is a <linkText>composite key[primary and foreign key constraints]</linkText><title></title> of a small number of narrow columns

trans-unit.source: Unique, or mostly unique
trans-unit.target: Unique, or mostly unique

trans-unit.source: Static - value is not frequently changed
trans-unit.target: Static - value is not frequently changed

trans-unit.source: Ever-increasing
trans-unit.target: Ever-increasing

trans-unit.source: (Optional) Fixed-width
trans-unit.target: (Optional) Fixed-width

trans-unit.source: (Optional) nonnull
trans-unit.target: (Optional) nonnull

trans-unit.source: The reason for the narrow property is that all other indexes on a table use the key values from the clustered index as lookup keys.
trans-unit.target: The reason for the narrow property is that all other indexes on a table use the key values from the clustered index as lookup keys.

trans-unit.source: In the example of a topic index at the back of a book, the clustered index is a page number and is a small number.
trans-unit.target: In the example of a topic index at the back of a book, the clustered index is a page number and is a small number.

trans-unit.source: If the chapter title were instead included in the clustered index, then the topic index would itself be much longer, because the key value would then be (chapter name, page number).
trans-unit.target: If the chapter title were instead included in the clustered index, then the topic index would itself be much longer, because the key value would then be (chapter name, page number).

trans-unit.source: The key should be static and ever-increasing to avoid having to maintain the physical location of the records (which means either moving records physically, or potentially fragmenting storage by splitting the pages where the records are stored).
trans-unit.target: The key should be static and ever-increasing to avoid having to maintain the physical location of the records (which means either moving records physically, or potentially fragmenting storage by splitting the pages where the records are stored).

trans-unit.source: The clustered index will be most valuable for queries that do the following:
trans-unit.target: The clustered index will be most valuable for queries that do the following:

trans-unit.source: Return a range of values by using operators such as BETWEEN, >, >=, <, and <=.
trans-unit.target: Return a range of values by using operators such as BETWEEN, >, >=, <, and <=.

trans-unit.source: After the row with the first value is found by using the clustered index, rows with subsequent indexed values are guaranteed to be physically adjacent.
trans-unit.target: After the row with the first value is found by using the clustered index, rows with subsequent indexed values are guaranteed to be physically adjacent.

trans-unit.source: Use JOIN clauses; typically these are foreign key columns.
trans-unit.target: Use JOIN clauses; typically these are foreign key columns.

trans-unit.source: Use ORDER BY, or GROUP BY clauses.
trans-unit.target: Use ORDER BY, or GROUP BY clauses.

trans-unit.source: An index on the columns specified in the ORDER BY or GROUP BY clause may remove the need for the Database Engine to sort the data, because the rows are already sorted.
trans-unit.target: An index on the columns specified in the ORDER BY or GROUP BY clause may remove the need for the Database Engine to sort the data, because the rows are already sorted.

trans-unit.source: This improves query performance.
trans-unit.target: This improves query performance.
